## Objective:
**Understand the basic financial tools & concepts used in assessing and comparing the value of technology investment.**

**Net Present Value:** it is also called Time Value of money. Which means a unit of money received in 1 year is less than a unit of money receive today.

Ex: $1 today is always worth more than $1 one year from today

### Question: Which one do you prefer?
1.	Do you wanna $100 today (or) 

2.	Do you wanna $100 a year from today?

A.	I can put in FD & earn 9% returns. When it comes to $100 a year from today I’ve lost interest. It is a basic economics. Feature cash flows are not worth as much as today. So, we need to discount.

B.	If I’ve a $100 a year from today. To make a comparison I need to discount back to time “0” today.


NPV = cfo/(1+r)^o + cf1/(1+r)^1 +………  
 

Present is basically saying you’re discounting all the cash flows to the present back to the Time ‘0’.
The present value is coming out the fact that you’re discounting everything back to time “zero” to the present & net is coming because some those cash flows may be (-)ve & some of them gonna be (+)ve.

So you’re netting out inflows & outflows. So that’s the reason you’re getting the word net present value. 
 Rule: 
 1. You usually shows outflows as (-) ve numbers &
 2. Inflows as (+) ve numbers**

 **In Finance you always discount cash flows before compare. You cannot compare cash flows across Time.**
